title.rendered: How Do I Get A Bioengineering Internship?

content.rendered:
Are you interested in genetic engineering and how we can further advance medicine and biology? If you are, then an internship in bioengineering is the perfect opportunity to get hands-on experience.

What does a bioengineering intern do?

Most bioengineering interns will find themselves concerned with both research and assisting with actual manufacturing efforts for their company. Bioengineering interns will work both independently and with a team towards a common goal–mainly in a lab setting.

How do I find a bioengineering internship?

If you’re wondering how to get a bioengineering internship for summer 2021, try looking on Handshake under filtered searches like “bioengineering internships near me.” Handshake allows you to focus on employers you want to work for and even network with past interns who may also be alumni from your school. And if you’re looking for a bioengineering internship in a particular location for summer 2021, try searching for openings by using filters like “biomedical engineering intern” or “bioengineering bay area.”

How do I get a bioengineering internship with no experience?

If you’re interested in getting a bioengineering internship, but have no prior experience, it’s key to play to your strengths and show employers that you’re eager to learn. You can search for bioengineering internships on Handshake to first get a feel of the requirements they usually list for internships. After that, list your resume and cover letter experiences and previous roles you’ve had where the skills translate over. For example, if you’ve taken a data analysis course or have had engineering bootcamp experience, mention it and how it relates to your desired role! 

When should I start applying for bioengineering internships?

For most positions, start searching for your internship sooner rather than later! If you are planning to have a summer bioengineering internship, we recommend starting to look for internship positions no later than the season prior. Many industries prefer to recruit as early as the fall, so staying up to date on fall virtual career fairs will be helpful in securing a role! Each company has different deadlines for applications, so sooner is usually better! If you’re searching for a role during the school year, it’s best to get on applying 3-6 months prior so you can inform your internship of your other obligations and classes.

It’s also really important to keep in mind that your university’s career services center will have great insight about specific recruitment periods at your school. Make sure to sign up for a meeting with your career advisor at the start of the school year for additional help in planning ahead!

How much do bioengineering interns make?

Because the internship roles that require bioengineering interns vary, there’s no standard answer for a bioengineering internship payscale. If you’re wondering how much your internship will pay, it might be best to inquire directly with the company you’re considering taking an internship with.. Some internship programs will offer only class credits, while many others are more keen to compensate their interns with an hourly rate or a set stipend.

What skills are relevant for bioengineering interns?

  • Strong problem solving skills
  • Analytical and level-headed
  • Strong displays of both leadership and teamwork
  • Great communication skills

Where do bioengineering interns work?

Bioengineering interns can take their learnings and work into a few different roles like Microbiologists, Engineering Technologists, and Environmental Engineers. They also can work for many different types of companies, like our constantly growing list of employers hiring now.

How do I write a cover letter for an internship?

Take a look at some great cover letter writing tips to boost your confidence and ace your internship application! And if you need a place to start, try our free cover letter template download here, or reach out to your school’s career center for personalized cover letter guidance.
